I know we are going off topic here, but please excuse me.  I've tried a
few=
 different tail utilities on windows over the years and the best has
to be =
the one the GNU one.  You can download cygwin which provides a
unix API for=
 windows.

If you install cygwin, http://sources.redhat.com/cygwin/, not on=
ly do
you get tail, but also grep, cat, awk, wc and others all invoked from=
 a
bash prompt.  Luvvly.

Dave

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Roge=
rs [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: 15 August 2001 13:29
To: 'jun=
it@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Recover from test hangs


Sorry ev=
eryone.  I attached the tail.exe to the previous post and that
caused some =
folks' email and virus clients to skip a beat.  If anyone is
interested in =
the tail program (freeware) let me know and I will put it
in
the files sect=
ion of the group.  For those who don't know what tail
is...
This is a windo=
ws port of the standard UNIX tail that allows you to
monitor
the end of a f=
ile as it is being written.  It is useful for log files or
debug files.  Yo=
u can also download it from
<http://www.rhazes.com/cgi-bin/Utilitiy_0.asp>
=

-Jason

    > -----Original Message-----
    > From: Jason Rogers [mailto:=
jason.rogers@...]
    > Sent: Wednesday, August 15, 2001 8:19 AM=

    > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
    > Subject: RE: [junit] Recover from =
test hangs
    > 
    > 
    > Which JDK are you using?  You could also use=
 the 
    > -Xrunhprof option (I think
    > it is only available 1.2.x +).=
  Use the attached tail.exe 
    > to tail the file.
    > See 
    > <http=
://java.sun.com/products/jdk/1.2/docs/guide/jvmpi/jvm
    > pi.html#hprof>
=
    > for how to interpret -Xrunhprof, but basically you are looking for
  =
  > ThreadStarts that don't have an associated ThreadEnd.  
    > This will=
 tell you
    > where possible hangs are happening.
    > 
    > -Jason

 >

    >     >

    >     > Run your tests =
with the text test runner.  When 
    > it's hung do a
    >     > Ctrl-Bre=
ak (on unix you have to send a signal, not sure 
    >     > which one).
  =
  >     > This causes the JVM to do a thread dump.  You can see a 
    >   =
  > stack trace of
    >     > each thread and hopefully find your deadlock=
.
